did.unittitle: Library Company of Philadelphia exhibition and publication records

bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials related to exhibitions held at the Library Company of Philadelphia. Included are catalogues of exhibitions from 1931 to 1939 and from 1969 to 1996. There are also typescripts of catalogue and exhibit label text for selected exhibitions in the 1930s and in 1973. Exhibitions from the 1990s are documented with exhibition checklists, label text, invitations and announcements, posters, records of funding, photographs, and catalogues. The collection also includes brochures and catalogues for exhibitions at other institutions for which the Library Company provided materials or speakers, and volumes published by the Library Company of Philadelphia. Titles include "Gothic Windows to Peacocks", "Legacies of Genius", "A Rising People", "Nineteenth-Century Photography in Philadelphia, "Quarter of a Millennium", "The Library of James Logan of Philadelphia" , "A Flock of Beautiful Birds", and "The Larder Invaded". There are also prepublication materials including galley proofs, manuscripts, notes, correspondence, photographs, and publicity.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
